o:DocumentProperties.o:Title: DIGITAL IMAGE SYSTEMS COME OF AGE (BUT WHEN WILL THEY GROW UP
o:DocumentProperties.o:Author: University Libraries

w:r.w:t: DIGITAL IMAGE SYSTEMS COME OF AGE (BUT WILL THEY EVER GROW UP?)
Image Service Demonstrator Project (ISDP), California Digital Library, 2003 to present
Visual Image User Study (VIUS), Pennsylvania State University, 2001-2003
Assess user needs for digital delivery of still images
Content is a (or the) primarily determinate of use. Some needs for content are local and dynamic.
student expect it & faculty sense that digital is "inevitable"
perception of increased labor and/or learning
Collections maintained by individuals are important resources. *
widespread (1 in 3 of all faculty – 1 in 4 students -- 44% of picture users)
often contain unique knowledge or perspectives & often clear rights
Collections maintained by individuals are poorly described. *
but detailed metadata often in the collector's head
for labor, advice, software, and/or applications
Many faculty interested in sharing with colleagues or students.
especially collaborative research & often teaching materials
both with desire to control the terms of sharing
Image tools should not be too closely tied to retrieval systems. *
Use often requires other systems (learning management, etc.)
Many want to edit images (resize, contrast, etc.)
Heavy image users want to choose their own viewer
In classrooms, portable media are still preferred to live connections
Aggregation (one-stop shopping) is especially desirable to students.
variations in descriptive practice - no equivalent of AACR2
Loss of context: which collection, where in collection, permitted uses
user contributed description, annotations, persistent "slide trays"
specific information on rights and permitted uses
Logistics are manifold (platforms, future migrations, etc.) Work and data flow integrity essential.
Partnerships among users, librarians, educational technologists, visual resource curators seem to have increasing value.
These items are the focus of the presentation for the Digital Library Federation Spring 2004 Forum.)
Image Service Demonstrator Project (ISDP), California Digital Library
only those with no other delivery
Image quality less of an obstacle
